;尹先生脱离现实的看法让他的人民付出了代价电力党（<小>;PPP;）亲爱的。这位前首席检察官两年前当选，承诺结束“帝国”总统职位，更加贴近普通民众。两年前，民主党及其姊妹党赢得议会选举，获得180个席位，这是韩国民主历史上最多的席位。这次议会选举的投票率是三十多年来最高的，<小>;民主党;集团却没有获得那么多席位。但它仍然给了<小>;人民党;重击，赢得了议会300个席位中的175个席位，而总统政党及其附属党赢得了108个席位。第三个政党重建韩国党（;RKP;）赢得了 12 个席位。如果RKP能够与;民主党合作，;两党将占据议会五分之三以上的席位，从而拥有快速通过法案的权力。消息传出后，包括人民党临时领导人韩东勋在内的多位高级官员都带着歉意辞职。愤世嫉俗的人会认为他们正在抛弃一艘正在下沉的船。尹先生建立国内遗产的能力正处于严重危险之中。

;尹先生在任期间的大部分时间里，他的负面评价一直徘徊在 30 多岁左右。对他的第一夫人的腐败指控以及他的政府无法解决与自二月份以来一直罢工的医生之间的纠纷，都无助于他的政党的选举前景。但最终，通胀和房价等钱包问题才是选民最关心的问题。 “物价太高，经济一如既往地糟糕，”33 岁的曹先生抱怨道，他是首尔富裕江南地区的一名选民。 “但总统对了解葱的价格不感兴趣。”

;

;;DP;'获得多数席位意味着尹先生将无法通过任何有意义的改革，除非他能够跨越两党。这似乎不太可能。尽管声称他想彻底改革国家，但总统几乎没有提出什么重要的立法，通过的立法更少。然而，他在两年任期内否决了九项法案，比任何一位前任总统在整个五年任期内否决的法案都要多。

;

;<小>;民主党;保住了多数席位，不太可能有妥协的心情。该党领导人李在明长期以来一直指责政府是由总统前同事组成的“检察官独裁政权”。 ;RPK;的领导人 Cho Kuk 在选举前表示，他希望总统“先成为跛脚鸭，然后成为死鸭子”。

;

;;PPP; 几乎没有吸引到它的对手。韩先生在整个竞选活动中暗示<小>;民主党;和<小>;民主共和党;的领导人都是罪犯。李先生;因贪污罪被起诉;，但他否认这些指控，并称自己是政治迫害的受害者。与此同时，曹先生正在对伪造文件和贿赂罪的定罪提出上诉，尽管韩先生将他与希特勒进行比较可能并不能证明这一点。

;反常尹先生可能会很高兴以反对派的不合作作为国内政策失败的借口。两年后，他的团队;努力表达< /a>; 解决国家问题的详细或足够雄心勃勃的计划。其中包括无法找到体面工作或买不起房子的年轻一代、人口迅速老龄化以及世界最低的生育率（仅为 0.72）。它的经济还依赖于出口，并且过度依赖少数企业集团，这意味着它正在努力应对美国和中国对世界贸易的重塑。至少现在，尹先生在国内方面没有取得任何进展，有人应该为此负责。

;;查克·舒默< /b>;，参议院民主党多数党领袖，公布了一项打击“法官选秀”的法案，即战略性地向特定法官提起诉讼的做法。舒默先生的计划要求当案例分配的结果会对全国或全州产生影响时进行随机分配，例如 ;2023 年的裁决;限制了联邦政府获得堕胎药物。

;;S;;OMETIMES IT'S; just a balloon.或者它可能是一架无人机。有些高速行驶并改变方向；有些则高速行驶。其他人徘徊，然后消失。传感器检测到其中一些。其他人则在雷达下飞行。 Unidentified flying objects (;UFO;s) have been part of popular lore for decades, but governments have lately been trying harder to figure out what is fantasy and what is fact. Private enterprise is starting to crowdsource ;UFO; data, hoping to provide governments and other institutions with evidence they can investigate.

;;;

;Enigma Labs, a private company founded in 2020, offers an app that enables users to upload images of ;UFO;s, along with descriptions and other data about them.在过去 18 个月中，它已收到约 15,000 份提交材料（参见地图 1）。 Enigma 使用机器学习和人类主持人来评估这些内容。 It reckons that around two-thirds are unidentified anomalous phenomena (;UAP;s), the new way of saying ;UFO; that sheds the little-green-man baggage of the old term. In other words, they exist but are mysterious.

;;

;;UAP;s come in many sizes and shapes, though circles and spheres are the most common (see chart). A tenth of witnesses reported anomalous flight patterns, such as erratic movements at high speeds. Almost a third said they did not see any sign that they had means of propulsion, such as a jet exhaust. Enigma says that in more than half of the sightings there were multiple witnesses, which helps add credibility.

;;
;;;
;

;Enigma's app is available only in English, so it is not surprising that sightings are concentrated in Anglophone countries, especially America. New Mexico stands out (see map 2). Among American states it reported the highest number of ;UAP;s in proportion to its population (California was top for sheer number of sightings). New Mexico has long been a hotspot for ;UFO; sightings that have given rise to kooky conspiracy theories. Enigma's data suggest that one of three possibilities is true: people in the state are primed to look for; UFO;s; there is something about the area that makes it a place with a high concentration of phenomena that look like ;UFO;s; or those theories aren't so kooky after all. 
;
;Enigma's early adopters appear to be the sort of people you might expect to be on the lookout. Of the more than 2,000 users who identified their professions, more than half are former or current members of their countries' armed forces or civilian pilots (see chart). But the company hopes that as ;UFO;-spotting comes to seem more respectable, its base of witnesses will widen. 
;
;Recently there has been rare bipartisan support in America's Congress for investigating them 。 A former intelligence officer told a ;congressional hearing; in 2023 that the government is harbouring non-human “biologics”. At the same event a retired navy commander testified that sailors and pilots had tracked objects that appeared to have capabilities “far superior” to the technology possessed by the armed forces. (The Pentagon released a report in March that concluded there was no evidence of “extraterrestrial technology”, though the origin of some ;UAP;s remains a mystery.) ;NASA;, America's space agency, recently appointed a director for UAP research. Bill Nelson, its chief, said that the conversation needed to shift “from sensationalism to science”. Whatever the ;UAP;s may be, they also pose a safety issue for air traffic: American pilots have reported several near-misses.

;

;Unsurprisingly the field attracts a lot of attention, not all of it positive. For that reason staff at Enigma prefer to stay anonymous. Their work could, for example, detect classified advances in aerospace technology or government surveillance programmes. Or it might help explain something in nature, such as weather or space phenomena. Alien-hunters will have their own theories. The company's boss—who goes only by “;A;”—told ;The Economist; that her staff are “rational problem solvers” who will go “wherever the data leads”. ;■;

;;A; ;decade ago; finance ministries were gripped by austerity fever.即使失业率高企、经济增长疲软，各国政府仍竭尽全力削减预算赤字。今天，情况已大不相同。在整个西方，大多数经济体的状况都较好。人们有工作。企业利润增长强劲。 And yet governments are spending a lot more than they are taking in.

;

;No government is more profligate than America's. This year the world's largest economy is projected to run a budget deficit (where spending exceeds taxation) of more than 7% of ;GDP;—a level unheard of outside recession and wartime.但它并不是唯一一个挥霍无度的国家。爱沙尼亚和芬兰这两个一向节俭的北欧国家目前正面临巨额预算赤字。 Last year Italy's deficit was as wide as in 2010-11, following the global financial crisis of 2007-09, and France's grew to 5.5% of ;GDP;, well above forecasts. “I am calling for a collective wake-up call to make choices in all of our public spending,” announced Bruno Le Maire, its finance minister, last month.

;;
;;
;

;Some countries have been more reserved. Last year Cyprus ran a surplus. Greece and Portugal—close to balancing their budgets—look like the model of fiscal rectitude even if they still have colossal debts. Still, the general direction is clear. ;The Economist ;has analysed data from 35 rich countries. Whereas in 2017-19 the median country in our sample; ;ran a budget surplus, last year it ran a budget deficit of close to 2.5% of ;GDP ;(see chart 1). Measures of “primary” deficits (excluding interest payments) and “structural” deficits (abstracting from the economic cycle) have also sharply widened.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Two factors explain the splurge. The first relates to taxes. Across the rich world, receipts are surprisingly weak. In America, revenue from income taxes deducted from pay fell slightly last year. Meanwhile, “non-withheld income taxes”, including on capital gains, tumbled by a quarter. Britain's capital-gains-tax take is running 11% below its recent high. And Japan's self-assessment tax take for this fiscal year, which includes some levies on capital gains, is on track to come in 4% below last year's.

;

;Taxmen are suffering because of market ructions in late 2022 and early 2023. Tech firms, which pay big salaries, let staff go, trimming income-tax takes. As share prices fell, it became more difficult for households and investors to sell shares for a profit, reducing the pool of capital gains. Last year few people made money from flipping houses as property prices dropped. Senior staff at private-equity firms, who often receive income in the form of investment returns rather than a conventional salary, had a bad year.

;

;The second factor is state spending. Following the whatever-it-takes fiscal policy of the covid-19 pandemic, governments have retrenched, but not fully. In Australia elderly people in care homes may still receive financial assistance during a covid outbreak. Only in mid-2023 did Germany completely wind down the job-protection schemes implemented during the pandemic. America is still paying out substantial tax refunds to small businesses that kept people on during lockdowns. In Italy a project concocted in 2020, designed to encourage homeowners to green their homes, has spiralled out of control, with the government so far disbursing support worth €200bn (or 10% of ;GDP;). The name of one of the schemes, “Superbonus”, would be amusing were it not so profligate.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Politicians have also become more prepared to intervene—and spend money—in order to right perceived wrongs. After Russia invaded Ukraine and energy prices soared, governments in Europe allocated about 4% of ;GDP ;to protect households and companies from the effects.包括波兰和波罗的海国家在内的一些国家现在在枪支和士兵上投入巨资。 President Joe Biden wants to forgive as much student debt as he can before America's presidential election in November.

;

;How long can the firehose keep blasting? At first glance, it looks like it could keep going for a while. Markets have gone on a tear, which will boost tax receipts. And a government's debt sustainability does not change solely owing to what happens to the budget deficit. It is also a product of overall public debt, economic growth, inflation and interest rates. Since the end of the pandemic, inflation has been high and growth has been solid. Although rates have risen, they remain fairly low by historical standards.

;
;;
;

;These conditions put politicians in a fiscal sweet spot (see chart 2). We calculate that in 2022-23 the median rich country was able to run a primary deficit of about 2% of ;GDP ;and still cut its public-debt-to-;GDP ;ratio 。 The nominal value of debt would have risen, but, helped by inflation, the size of the economy would have risen by even more. A few countries faced an even more favourable environment. Italy's debt ratio has fallen by about ten percentage points of ;GDP ;from its peak in 2021, despite its loose fiscal policy. France's ratio has edged down, too. Greece—combining favourable economic conditions with tight fiscal policy—has seen its debt-to-;gdp; ratio fall by a stunning 50 percentage points.

;;

;American exceptionalism

;

;Now that is changing, however. The interest rates facing governments are not yet falling, even as economic growth and inflation come down. This is already making the fiscal arithmetic more daunting. For instance, the Italian government's primary position consistent with a stable debt ratio has fallen from a deficit of 1% of ;GDP ;last year to a surplus of 2% in this one, according to our calculations. America is in a pretty similar position. Further falls in inflation, a slowdown in growth or higher rates would make it more difficult still for governments to stabilise their debt.

;

;Small wonder that talk of fiscal consolidation has recently become louder. The Italian government believes it will soon be reprimanded by the ;EU ;for its stance. In Britain the opposition Labour Party, which hopes to take power before long, promises fiscal rectitude. The French government talks about cuts to health spending and unemployment benefits. America is the outlier. In the world's leading economy, the conversation still has not turned. Ahead of the election, Donald Trump and Mr Biden promise tax cuts for millions of voters. But fiscal logic is remorseless. Whether they like it or not, the era of free-spending politicians will have to come to an end. ;■;
